article_title: Fewer Texans sign up for ACA
article_text:
Fewer Texans sign up for ACA

Photo: Screenshot /Tribune News Service By Nov. 28, the number of Texans who enrolled through...

Forty percent fewer Texans signed up for coverage on the federally mandated health insurance exchange during the first month of open enrollment, compared with a year ago, according to the U.S. Health and Human Services Department.

article_metadata.description: Forty percent fewer Texans signed up for coverage on the federally mandated health insurance exchange during the first month of open enrollment, compared with a year ago, according to the U.S. Health and Human Services Department.  The signup period for coverage through the Affordable Care Act’s marketplace last year was slightly different, as open enrollment began Nov. 15, 2014.  Karen Love, chief operating officer at Community Health Choice, a Houston managed care organization that offers health plans on the federal marketplace, said there could be another last-minute rush this year.  Just before enrollment began this year, Health and Human Service Secretary Sylvia Burwell lowered expectations, predicting a modest increase nationwide in 2016 of only about 1 million people.  [...] that the marketplace enrollment is in its third year, Moto believes that many people, even those who have no tradition of buying health insurance, are becoming accustomed to the idea and importance of coverage.  Nationally, more than 16 million people have gained health insurance coverage since the Affordable Care Act went into effect.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam, Houston Chronicle

og.description: Forty percent fewer Texans signed up for coverage on the federally mandated health insurance exchange during the first month of open enrollment, compared with a year ago, according to the U.S. Health and Human Services Department.  The signup period for coverage through the Affordable Care Act’s marketplace last year was slightly different, as open enrollment began Nov. 15, 2014.  Karen Love, chief operating officer at Community Health Choice, a Houston managed care organization that offers health plans on the federal marketplace, said there could be another last-minute rush this year.  Just before enrollment began this year, Health and Human Service Secretary Sylvia Burwell lowered expectations, predicting a modest increase nationwide in 2016 of only about 1 million people.  [...] that the marketplace enrollment is in its third year, Moto believes that many people, even those who have no tradition of buying health insurance, are becoming accustomed to the idea and importance of coverage.  Nationally, more than 16 million people have gained health insurance coverage since the Affordable Care Act went into effect.
